rules.title: Minimum Lot Dimensions for New Lots
rules.category: Lot Size & Lot Area (incl. gross vs net)
rules.short_summary: New lots must meet minimum width and depth requirements
rules.summary: The subdivision ordinance requires new lots to have minimum dimensions to ensure adequate development space and maintain neighborhood character. All new lots must meet both width and depth requirements simultaneously.

requirements.setting: minimum width of 60 feet AND minimum depth of 100 feet

inclusions: Applies to all new lots created through subdivision
Both width and depth requirements must be met simultaneously
exclusions: Does not apply to existing lots of record
Flag lots have different requirements
rules.reasoning: To ensure adequate space for development while maintaining neighborhood character and streetscape continuity

rules.title: Minimum and Maximum Lot Areas by Zone
rules.category: Lot Size & Lot Area (incl. gross vs net)
rules.short_summary: Lot areas must fall within zone-specific minimum and maximum limits
rules.summary: Five R-1 zones have specific minimum and maximum lot area requirements that reflect and preserve traditional lotting patterns developed through annexation. Each zone has distinct area requirements to maintain neighborhood character.

requirements.setting: minimum 6,000 sf and maximum 9,999 sf
minimum 7,000 sf and maximum 13,999 sf
minimum 8,000 sf and maximum 15,999 sf
minimum 10,000 sf and maximum 19,999 sf
minimum 20,000 sf and maximum 39,999 sf

inclusions: Applies to all lots within R-1 zoning districts
Requirements vary by specific R-1 zone designation
exclusions: Exceptions allowed for lot line removal to eliminate non-conformities with no net loss of housing
Exceptions for combining adjacent substandard lots less than 25' wide with no net loss of housing
Exceptions where resultant number of lots increases or stays same with no net loss of housing
rules.reasoning: To preserve traditional lotting patterns and neighborhood character while allowing flexibility for housing preservation

rules.title: Substandard Lot Definition and Criteria
rules.category: Lot Size & Lot Area (incl. gross vs net)
rules.short_summary: Lots with insufficient width, depth, or area are classified as substandard
rules.summary: Substandard lots are those that fail to meet minimum dimensional requirements. These lots are subject to special regulations including height restrictions and modified setback requirements.

requirements.setting: width less than 50 feet OR depth less than 83 feet AND area less than or equal to 83% of minimum zone lot size

inclusions: Both dimensional and area criteria must be evaluated
Applies to all R-1 zones with zone-specific area thresholds
rules.reasoning: To identify lots requiring special development regulations due to size constraints

rules.title: Gross vs Net Lot Area Calculation
rules.category: Lot Size & Lot Area (incl. gross vs net)
rules.short_summary: Net lot area excludes certain areas from gross lot area for development calculations
rules.summary: Development potential is based on net lot area. While gross and net lot area are the same for most lots, certain areas must be excluded from gross lot area to establish net lot area for development calculations.

requirements.qualifier: lots with street right-of-way within boundaries
requirements.setting: exclude street right-of-way area from gross lot area
exclude pole portion from gross lot area
exclude creek channel area from gross lot area

inclusions: Applies to all lots where excluded areas are present
Net lot area is used for all development potential calculations
exclusions: Private access easements for flag lots are NOT excluded from the lot area
rules.reasoning: To ensure development calculations are based on actually usable lot area

rules.title: Maximum Lot Coverage Ratio
rules.short_summary: Lot coverage limited to 35% of lot area with additional 5% for specific features
rules.summary: Lot coverage describes how much of the lot is covered by structures. The maximum allowable coverage is 35% of the lot size, with an additional 5% permitted for covered patios, canopies, and roof overhangs beyond 4 feet.

requirements.setting: maximum lot coverage of 35% of lot area

requirements.qualifier: covered patios, canopies, and roof overhangs beyond 4 feet
requirements.setting: additional 5% lot coverage permitted

inclusions: Includes footprints of all structures (main residence, covered parking, tool sheds, covered pool equipment)
Includes projecting elements (balconies, stairways, porches, patio covers)
Includes decking exceeding 30 inches above grade
Includes roof overhangs or eaves exceeding 4 feet (portion beyond 4 feet)
Includes swimming pools and spas exceeding 30 inches above grade
exclusions: Excludes roof overhangs up to 4 feet
Excludes uncovered structures less than 30 inches above grade
rules.reasoning: To control building density and maintain open space while allowing reasonable development

rules.title: Gross Floor Area Calculation Method
rules.short_summary: GFA calculated as 45% of first 5,000 sf plus 30% of excess area
rules.summary: Allowable gross floor area is calculated using a tiered system: 45% of the first 5,000 sf of lot area plus 30% of any portion exceeding 5,000 sf. This system allows larger lots more floor area while maintaining proportionality.

requirements.setting: maximum 45% can be counted toward gross floor area
maximum 30% of excess area can be counted toward gross floor area

inclusions: Sum of all floors in main structure measured to outside of exterior stud walls
Stairwells at all floors and areas greater than 50% enclosed and covered
Covered parking and accessory buildings greater than 120 square feet
Spaces meeting criteria for second and third floor equivalents
rules.reasoning: To control building mass while allowing proportionally more floor area on larger lots

rules.title: Maximum Main House Size Limit
rules.short_summary: Main house cannot exceed 6,000 sf regardless of lot size
rules.summary: The main house has an absolute maximum size limit of 6,000 sf, regardless of the calculated allowable gross floor area based on lot size. This prevents oversized houses even on very large lots.

requirements.setting: maximum size of 6,000 sf

inclusions: Applies to main house only, not total development on lot
Absolute limit regardless of lot size or calculated FAR
exclusions: Does not apply to accessory structures
Does not limit total development on lot beyond FAR calculations
rules.reasoning: To prevent oversized main houses that would be out of scale with neighborhood character

rules.title: Porch Floor Area Calculation Based on Openness
rules.short_summary: Roofed first floor porches count toward GFA only if less than 50% open
rules.summary: Roofed porches on the first floor are evaluated for openness to determine if they count toward gross floor area. Porches that are at least 50% open on their perimeter do not count, while those less than 50% open count once toward GFA.

requirements.qualifier: roofed first floor porches with less than 50% open perimeter
requirements.setting: count once toward gross floor area

requirements.qualifier: roofed first floor porches with 50% or more open perimeter
requirements.setting: do not count toward gross floor area

inclusions: Openness measured by comparing open vs closed segments of porch perimeter
Segments abutting house walls are considered closed
50% facade area must be open for segment to be considered open
Height measured from porch floor to intersection with roof material
exclusions: Non-roofed porches generally do not count
Applies only to first floor porches
rules.reasoning: To encourage open porches that contribute to streetscape while controlling enclosed space

rules.title: Entry Feature Height-Based Floor Area Calculation
rules.short_summary: Entry features count once if under 12' high, twice if over 12' high
rules.summary: Roofed entry features on the first floor are classified as regular or vaulted based on height. Features 12 feet or less count once toward GFA, while those over 12 feet (vaulted) count twice, regardless of design or openness.

requirements.qualifier: roofed entry features 12 feet or less in height
requirements.setting: count once toward gross floor area

requirements.qualifier: roofed entry features over 12 feet in height (vaulted)
requirements.setting: count twice toward gross floor area

inclusions: Height measured from grade to top of roof material
Applies regardless of design including openness
Footprint measured to outside material of entry feature
rules.reasoning: To account for the increased visual mass and impact of taller entry features

rules.title: Recessed Porch Floor Area Exemption Criteria
rules.short_summary: Recessed porches exempt from GFA if under 10' deep, below 2nd floor, and open
rules.summary: Recessed porches on the ground floor do not count toward gross floor area if they meet all three criteria: depth less than 10 feet, ceiling below second floor level, and exterior side substantially open.

requirements.qualifier: recessed ground floor porches meeting all criteria
requirements.setting: do not count toward gross floor area

requirements.qualifier: recessed ground floor porches failing any criteria
requirements.setting: count toward gross floor area, twice if over 17 feet high

inclusions: All three criteria must be met: depth < 10', ceiling below 2nd floor, exterior side substantially open
One-story construction considered less than 17' above finished floor
If porch space is higher than 17', counts twice as 2nd story equivalency
rules.reasoning: To encourage open, human-scale recessed porches while controlling enclosed space

rules.title: Upper Floor Outdoor Area Floor Area Calculation
rules.short_summary: Roofed outdoor areas on upper floors count toward GFA regardless of design
rules.summary: Outdoor areas on upper levels that are roofed count toward gross floor area regardless of whether the sides are open. An area is considered roofed if the eave over that area is deeper than the eave over the rest of the building.

requirements.qualifier: roofed outdoor areas on upper floors
requirements.setting: count once toward gross floor area

inclusions: Includes balconies, decks, and outdoor areas on upper floors
Roofed determination based on eave depth comparison
Applies regardless of side openness
Pop-out balconies subject to same evaluation
exclusions: Areas with eave same size as rest of house considered open
Substantially open arbors may not count
rules.reasoning: To account for covered outdoor space that adds to building mass and visual impact

rules.title: Attic Space Floor Area Based on Head Clearance
rules.short_summary: Attic areas with 5+ feet head clearance count toward GFA
rules.summary: On all accessible floors, areas with at least 5 feet of head clearance count toward gross floor area regardless of floor plan or actual usage. This includes attic spaces, closets, and perimeter spaces under sloped roofs.

requirements.qualifier: accessible floor areas with 5+ feet head clearance
requirements.setting: count toward gross floor area

requirements.qualifier: attic areas with less than 5 feet head clearance
requirements.setting: do not count toward gross floor area

inclusions: Applies to all accessible floors including attics
Measurements from top of floor to underside of rafter
Includes closets and perimeter spaces
500 sf exemption for unusable attic space in Category 1 & 2 historic homes
rules.reasoning: To account for usable space that contributes to building mass even if not shown on floor plans

rules.title: Second and Third Floor Equivalency Height Thresholds
rules.short_summary: Areas above 17' count twice, above 26' count three times toward GFA
rules.summary: Areas higher than 17 feet and 26 feet above the first floor that do not already count as floor area (such as open atrium spaces and inaccessible attic spaces) count toward gross floor area as 2nd and 3rd floor equivalencies.

requirements.qualifier: areas 17-26 feet above first floor not otherwise counted
requirements.setting: count twice toward gross floor area (2nd floor equivalency)

requirements.qualifier: areas over 26 feet above first floor not otherwise counted
requirements.setting: count three times toward gross floor area (3rd floor equivalency)

inclusions: Applies to open atrium spaces and inaccessible attic spaces
Stairwells measured same way as vaulted ceiling spaces
200 sf exemption for 3rd floor equivalency where roof pitch is 4:12 or steeper
exclusions: Does not apply to areas already counted as floor area
rules.reasoning: To account for voluminous spaces that contribute to building mass even if not used or accessible

rules.title: Bay Window Floor Area Exemption Criteria
rules.short_summary: Bay windows exempt from GFA if 18+ inches above floor, supported by brackets, 50%+ glass
rules.summary: Bay windows meeting specific design criteria are considered decorative architectural features and do not count toward gross floor area. They must be at least 18 inches above floor joists, supported by corbels/brackets rather than solid walls, and have at least 50% glass surface.

requirements.qualifier: bay windows meeting all design criteria
requirements.setting: do not count toward gross floor area

requirements.qualifier: bay windows failing any design criteria
requirements.setting: count toward gross floor area

inclusions: Must be at least 18 inches above floor joists
Must have exterior supports like corbels/brackets, not solid walls
Must be at least 50% glass surface
Maximum 2 feet projection from facade
Bay windows extending higher than structure's roof considered dormers
exclusions: Floor joists continuing into bay window disqualifies exemption
Exterior skirt walls (angled or straight) disqualify exemption
Less than 50% glass surface disqualifies exemption
rules.reasoning: To encourage attractive architectural features while preventing abuse of projections to gain floor area

rules.title: Fireplace and Chimney Floor Area Calculation
rules.short_summary: Fireplaces count once toward GFA; upper floor chimneys do not count
rules.summary: All configurations of fireplaces, chimneys, and buttresses count once toward gross floor area regardless of configuration or design. However, chimneys on upper floors do not count. Detached fireplaces are treated as accessory structures.

requirements.qualifier: fireplaces, chimneys, and buttresses on ground level
requirements.setting: count once toward gross floor area
do not count toward gross floor area
count toward FAR as accessory structures
count toward lot coverage

inclusions: Applies to all fireplace configurations and designs
2000 ordinance prohibits new wood-burning fireplaces
rules.reasoning: To account for structural mass while recognizing upper floor chimneys have minimal impact

rules.title: Miscellaneous Projection Height Threshold
rules.short_summary: Sheds, planters, and projections over 5' high count toward GFA
rules.summary: Miscellaneous appendages such as tool sheds, equipment enclosures, and playhouses that exceed 5 feet in height count toward gross floor area regardless of configuration or design. These structures may not be located in required yards.

requirements.qualifier: sheds, planters, and projections over 5 feet high
requirements.setting: count toward gross floor area

requirements.qualifier: sheds, planters, and projections 5 feet or less high
requirements.setting: do not count toward gross floor area

inclusions: Includes tool sheds, equipment enclosures, playhouses
Height is the determining factor regardless of other characteristics
exclusions: May not be located in required yards
Noise-producing equipment may not be located in required yards
rules.reasoning: To control visual impact of auxiliary structures while allowing small utility features

rules.title: Standard Setback Requirements by Zone
rules.short_summary: Setback requirements vary by R-1 zone designation with contextual or minimum standards
rules.summary: Standard setbacks apply in most cases and vary by zone district. Front setbacks use contextual setbacks if greater than 30 feet, otherwise 20-foot minimum applies. Other setbacks are fixed by zone.

requirements.setting: front: contextual or 20', rear: 20', interior side: 6', street side: 16'
front: contextual or 20', rear: 20', interior side: 8', street side: 16'
front: 10', rear: 20', interior side: see zone, street side: n/a
front: contextual or 20', rear: 20', interior side: see zone, street side: 16'
front: contextual or 20', rear: 20', interior side: see zone, street side: 10'

inclusions: Contextual setback applies if average existing setbacks on block is 30' or greater
Special setbacks may override standard setbacks on designated streets
rules.reasoning: To maintain neighborhood character while providing flexibility for contextual compatibility

rules.title: Contextual Front Setback Calculation Method
rules.short_summary: Contextual setbacks apply when average existing setbacks exceed 30 feet
rules.summary: Contextual setbacks apply only if the average of existing setbacks on the same side of the block is 30 feet or greater. The calculation excludes certain lot types and uses a specific methodology to determine the average.

requirements.setting: use calculated average setback if 30 feet or greater
use standard 20-foot front setback

inclusions: Must have more than 3 lots on block (including project lot)
If block over 600' long, consider only lots within 600' (max 10 lots)
If 5 or more remaining lots, exclude smallest and largest setbacks
Calculate average of remaining lots including subject lot
exclusions: Exclude flag lots from calculation
Exclude multi-family use with 3+ units
Exclude corner lots facing cross street
If subject lot is corner lot, consider pattern on street that garage faces
rules.reasoning: To ensure new development is compatible with established neighborhood patterns

rules.title: Setback Measurement from Easements
rules.short_summary: Setbacks measured from easement edge regardless of lot line location
rules.summary: Some easements affect setback measurements. Setbacks must be measured from the edge of creek easements and public street easements regardless of where the actual lot lines are located.

requirements.setting: measure setbacks from easement edge, not lot line
measure setbacks from easement edge, not lot line
measure setbacks from lot line (most utility easements do not affect setbacks)

inclusions: Applies to creek easements and public street easements
Sidewalk location does not indicate lot line position
exclusions: Most public utility easements do not affect setbacks
rules.reasoning: To ensure setbacks provide intended separation from actual constraints and public areas

rules.title: Allowable Rear Yard Encroachment for Main Dwelling
rules.short_summary: Main dwelling may encroach up to 6' into rear setback with 14' minimum maintained
rules.summary: A portion of the main dwelling no wider than half the maximum width may encroach into the rear setback at ground floor only. Standard lots allow 6' encroachment with 14' minimum setback; back-to-back corner lots allow 10' encroachment with 10' minimum setback.

requirements.setting: may encroach up to 6' into rear yard maintaining 14' minimum setback

requirements.qualifier: main dwelling on back-to-back corner lots
requirements.setting: may encroach up to 10' into rear yard maintaining 10' minimum setback
maximum width of half the building width

inclusions: Ground floor only
Must be contiguous with existing structure
Only for legally constructed structures
Only once in the life of the structure
exclusions: Multiple protrusions not permitted
Not allowed for structures built with variance or home-improvement exception
rules.reasoning: To allow reasonable expansion while maintaining adequate rear yard space

rules.title: Extension of Existing Setback Encroachments
rules.short_summary: Existing legal encroachments may be extended under specific conditions
rules.summary: Existing walls that legally encroach into required setbacks may be extended at the same setback distance, in one direction only, at ground floor only, subject to minimum setback requirements and length limitations.

requirements.qualifier: existing side yard encroachments at least 5' from property line
requirements.setting: may extend up to length of existing wall or 20', whichever is less

requirements.qualifier: existing front yard encroachments at least 14' from property line
requirements.setting: may extend up to length of existing wall, combined length not exceeding half building width

requirements.qualifier: existing street-side yard encroachments at least 10' from property line
requirements.setting: may extend up to length of existing wall or 20', whichever is less

inclusions: Ground floor only
One direction only
Must be contiguous with existing encroachment
Only for legally constructed structures without variance
Only once in the life of the structure
Requires retention of non-complying wall
exclusions: Walls not meeting minimum setbacks cannot be extended
Cannot be stepped back and then extended
Multiple protrusions not permitted
rules.reasoning: To allow reasonable expansion of existing legal non-conformities while maintaining setback intent

rules.title: Primary Daylight Plane Side Setback Measurement
rules.short_summary: 45-degree daylight plane measured from 10' above average grade at side lot lines
rules.summary: The primary daylight plane regulates structures within the buildable area. Side daylight planes are measured at a 45-degree angle starting from 10 feet above average grade at the side lot lines.

requirements.setting: must comply with 45-degree daylight plane from side lot lines
10 feet above average grade at lot line

inclusions: Measured from average grade established using existing grade before grading
Average grade calculated from grade at building midpoint and closest point on adjacent lot
Applies to structures in buildable area only
exclusions: Structures in rear/side yards regulated by accessory-structure daylight plane
No front daylight plane exists
rules.reasoning: To preserve privacy and natural light access to adjacent properties

rules.title: Primary Daylight Plane Rear Setback Measurement
rules.short_summary: 60-degree daylight plane measured from rear setback line
rules.summary: The rear daylight plane is measured at a 60-degree angle from the rear setback line. Protrusions are allowed with specific dimensional limits and separation requirements.

requirements.setting: must comply with 60-degree daylight plane from rear setback line
maximum 7.5' length each, 5' minimum separation, 15' cumulative length per side

inclusions: Applies to rear elevations of structures
Protrusions limited to 24' maximum height
Same rules apply to side protrusions
exclusions: No front daylight plane
rules.reasoning: To balance development flexibility with neighbor privacy and light access

rules.title: Allowable Daylight Plane Protrusions
rules.short_summary: Specific architectural features may extend beyond daylight plane with limitations
rules.summary: Certain architectural features are allowed to extend beyond the daylight plane with specific dimensional and design limitations to maintain the intent of the daylight plane while allowing reasonable architectural expression.

requirements.setting: may extend up to 15' above maximum building height
may extend beyond daylight plane to meet Building Code clearances

requirements.qualifier: dormers, roof decks, gables, or similar features
requirements.setting: maximum 7.5' long each, 15' cumulative, 5' minimum separation, 24' maximum height
maximum 2' protrusion (excluding usable interior space)

inclusions: Each feature type has specific dimensional limits
Some features limited by cumulative length
Height restrictions apply to certain features
exclusions: Flat or continuous walls not allowed as eave protrusions
Enclosures usable for interior space not allowed as eave protrusions
rules.reasoning: To allow necessary and attractive architectural features while maintaining daylight plane intent

rules.title: Accessory Structure General Standards
rules.short_summary: Accessory structures must be incidental, detached, and meet size-based permit requirements
rules.summary: Non-dwelling accessory structures have no minimum lot size requirements but must meet specific standards for use, location, and permitting based on size. All accessory structures count toward lot coverage.

requirements.setting: must be incidental to main dwelling, detached by 3' minimum, no kitchen allowed
require building permit and count toward gross floor area
maximum two plumbing fixtures allowed
count toward total lot coverage

inclusions: Use must be incidental to main dwelling
Must be detached by at least 3' from main dwelling
No kitchen allowed in any accessory structure
exclusions: Structures under 120 sf do not require building permit but must comply with zoning
rules.reasoning: To allow reasonable accessory uses while maintaining residential character and controlling development intensity

rules.title: Accessory Structure Location Restrictions
rules.short_summary: Accessory structures in setbacks have specific location and use restrictions
rules.summary: Accessory structures located in required setbacks face additional restrictions on location, coverage, use, and height compared to those in the buildable area.

requirements.setting: prohibited in front yard, street-side yard, and rear yard of through lots
may not cover more than 50% of rear yard area
may not be used for sleeping or living
subject to accessory-structure height and daylight plane regulations

inclusions: May be located in rear and interior side yards only
Subject to special height and daylight plane rules
Still require permits if over 120 sf
exclusions: Cannot be located in front yard, street-side yard, or rear yard of through lots
Cannot be used for habitation
rules.reasoning: To allow accessory structures while protecting required open space and neighborhood character

rules.title: Accessory Structure Daylight Plane Requirements
rules.short_summary: Accessory structures near lot lines subject to special daylight plane starting at 8' above grade
rules.summary: Accessory structures located near rear and side lot lines must comply with a special daylight plane that starts at 8 feet above average grade with a maximum building height of 12 feet.

requirements.qualifier: accessory structures near side lot lines
requirements.setting: comply with daylight plane starting 8' above grade at side lot line

requirements.qualifier: accessory structures near rear lot lines
requirements.setting: comply with daylight plane starting 8' above grade at rear lot line
maximum height of 12 feet

inclusions: Daylight plane slopes inward from lot line
Hipped-gable roof often best solution for compliance
Maximum 12' height limit applies
rules.reasoning: To minimize impact on neighboring properties while allowing reasonable accessory structures

rules.title: Detached Garage and Carport Location Requirements
rules.short_summary: Detached parking structures must be 75' from front or in rear half if lot under 95' deep
rules.summary: Detached garages and carports may be located in rear or interior side yards if at least 75 feet from the front lot line and 20 feet from street-side lot line. On lots less than 95 feet deep, they may be in the rear half of the lot.

requirements.setting: minimum 75' from front lot line and 20' from street-side lot line

requirements.qualifier: detached garages/carports on lots under 95' deep
requirements.setting: may be located in rear half of lot
must comply with fire-rated walls and roof materials
minimum 3' from any lot line

inclusions: Special setback exception available for covered parking on shallow lots
Subject to stricter daylight plane when using setback exception
Fire rating required when at lot line
exclusions: Setback exception applies only to parking structures, not other accessory structures
rules.reasoning: To accommodate parking needs while maintaining adequate separation and fire safety

rules.title: Noise-Producing Equipment Location Restrictions
rules.short_summary: Noise equipment prohibited in most yards, limited encroachment in street-side yard
rules.summary: Noise-producing equipment may not be located in front, rear, or interior-side yards. Limited encroachment up to 6 feet is allowed in street-side yards. All equipment must meet City Noise Ordinance requirements.

requirements.setting: prohibited in front, rear, and interior-side yards
may encroach up to 6 feet
must meet City Noise Ordinance Chapter 9.10 requirements
must be insulated and housed unless waived by Planning Department

inclusions: Includes pool equipment, air conditioning units, generators
Planning Department may waive housing requirement for equipment in buildable area
Replacement equipment must conform where feasible
exclusions: May not encroach into front or rear yards from street-side yard
rules.reasoning: To minimize noise impacts on neighbors while allowing necessary mechanical equipment

rules.title: Required Parking Spaces and Location
rules.short_summary: Two parking spaces required per dwelling, prohibited in front yard and first 10' of street-side
rules.summary: Two parking spaces are required on each lot per dwelling unit. They may not be located in the required front yard or the first 10 feet of the required street-side yard. One space must be covered.

requirements.setting: two parking spaces required on lot
must be covered
prohibited in front yard and first 10' of street-side yard
prohibited except by variance

inclusions: Applies to main dwelling and 2nd dwelling units
Covered parking must be provided
Tandem parking acceptable for second space
exclusions: No underground parking except by variance
rules.reasoning: To ensure adequate parking while maintaining attractive streetscapes

rules.title: Parking Space Dimensional Requirements
rules.short_summary: Uncovered spaces 8.5'x18', covered spaces 10'x20', 7' vertical clearance
rules.summary: Parking spaces have specific dimensional requirements based on whether they are covered or uncovered. Covered spaces require larger dimensions and must be kept clear of other uses.

requirements.setting: minimum 8.5' x 18'
minimum 10' x 20' clear inside dimension
minimum 20' x 20' clear inside
minimum 7' vertical clearance
minimum 3' from main dwelling

inclusions: Clear area must be free of other uses (water heaters, washers, etc.)
Dimensions are interior clear dimensions for covered spaces
rules.reasoning: To ensure parking spaces are adequately sized and functional

rules.title: Driveway Standards and Materials
rules.short_summary: Driveways must meet width and material standards with Public Works approval
rules.summary: Driveways may use permeable or impermeable materials meeting Public Works standards. Specific width requirements and material restrictions apply near public right-of-way.

requirements.setting: must meet Public Works standards for materials

requirements.qualifier: driveway surface within 10' of public right-of-way
requirements.setting: may not be loose material like gravel
minimum 10' width
minimum 8' width
minimum 20' separation between cuts
maximum 40% of required front yard

inclusions: 2nd dwelling units must share common driveway
Street-work permit required for public right-of-way work
Turns must be deemed maneuverable by Transportation Division
Encouraged: maximum one curb cut per frontage, 50' from intersection
rules.reasoning: To ensure safe, functional driveways while maintaining neighborhood appearance

rules.title: Contextual Garage Placement Determination
rules.short_summary: Garage placement regulated by predominant neighborhood pattern when it exists
rules.summary: Contextual garage placement applies when there is a predominant neighborhood pattern. The determination involves analyzing existing garages on the block and categorizing them as front-half or rear-half pattern lots.

requirements.qualifier: projects where contextual garage placement applies
requirements.setting: must place garage according to predominant neighborhood pattern

inclusions: Consider only lots within 600' or 10 closest lots if block over 600' long
For corner lots, consider pattern on street that garage faces
Divide lots into front-half pattern and rear-half pattern categories
Lots with no garage count as rear-half pattern
Predominant pattern is category with more than half the lots
exclusions: Exclude flag lots from analysis
Exclude multi-family use with 3+ units
Exclude corner lots from analysis
rules.reasoning: To ensure garage placement is compatible with established neighborhood character

rules.title: Basement Floor Area Exemption Criteria
rules.short_summary: Basements exempt from GFA if first floor is 3' or less above grade
rules.summary: Basements, even habitable ones, do not count as floor area if the first floor is no more than 3 feet above grade. This exemption recognizes that below-grade space does not contribute to apparent building mass.

requirements.qualifier: basements with first floor 3' or less above grade
requirements.setting: do not count toward gross floor area

requirements.qualifier: basements with first floor over 3' above grade
requirements.setting: count toward gross floor area

inclusions: Applies to all basement areas including habitable spaces
First floor height measurement determines exemption
exclusions: May not be located in special flood hazard areas
May not extend beyond building footprint
May not encroach into required yards except where main dwelling permitted
rules.reasoning: To allow below-grade development that does not impact building appearance or mass

rules.title: Light Well and Stairwell Standards
rules.short_summary: Light wells limited to 3' width, 30% of basement perimeter, with encroachment limits
rules.summary: Light wells and stairwells have specific dimensional limits and location restrictions. They may not face the front yard and are limited in width, total length, and encroachment into required yards.

requirements.setting: maximum 3' interior width
maximum 30% of basement perimeter length
maximum 3' encroachment, minimum 3' from lot line
maximum 4' encroachment
maximum 15' total length on all sides

inclusions: May not be located facing front yard
Must not harm neighboring trees
Require Public Works drainage system approval
Measurements based on interior dimensions excluding structure
exclusions: Prohibited on front-facing side of structure
rules.reasoning: To allow necessary light and access while minimizing impact on required yards

rules.title: Below-Grade Patio Standards
rules.short_summary: Below-grade patios limited to 200 sf each, 2% of lot area total, with separation requirements
rules.summary: Below-grade patios have size limitations both individually and cumulatively, plus separation requirements and location restrictions. They require architectural compatibility and screening.

requirements.setting: maximum 200 sf each
maximum 2% of lot area or 200 sf, whichever is greater
minimum 10' apart
maximum 2'
maximum 4'
maximum 15' combined length

inclusions: May not face front yard
Required stairway egress not included in 200 sf limitation
Must be architecturally compatible with residence
Must be screened from off-site views
Overhangs/canopies count toward lot coverage
Must not harm neighboring trees
Require drainage system approval
exclusions: Prohibited on front-facing side
rules.reasoning: To allow outdoor living space while controlling visual and privacy impacts

rules.title: Attached Second Dwelling Unit Standards
rules.short_summary: Attached ADUs limited to 450 sf on qualifying lots with specific design requirements
rules.summary: Attached second dwelling units are allowed on lots meeting minimum size requirements. They are limited to 450 sf, 17' height, and must meet specific parking and design standards.
